webTitle: Setting up Standard Life subsidiaries outside Scotland is sensible idea

fields.bodyText: Prod most chief executives of big Scottish companies on the subject of Scottish independence and, for the past year, the responses have followed a theme: nothing can usefully be said until the state of Scotland's proposed post-independence balance sheet, as it were, becomes clear. This cop-out, designed to avoid flak from any quarter, couldn't last forever. Public companies are owned by shareholders and have customers to serve. Both constituencies want to know the directors are awake. Seven months from the vote, Standard Life is merely stating the bleedin' obvious when it says that "a number of material issues remain uncertain" and that some of the risks look serious for a financial services company. Not knowing what currency an independent Scotland would use clearly ranks as a very large uncertainty. The same applies to the rate of corporation tax. And, crucially for investment firms, what regime would apply on consumer protection and individual taxation on products such as ISAs? In the circumstances, setting up a few subsidiaries in the rest of the UK is a reasonable response by Standard Life. The measure is "precautionary", says chief executive David Nish, but it's also clear that Standard Life is deadly serious about shifting operations southwards if that's where it perceives its interests, and customers' interests, to lie. This was not a cosmetic announcement. If the assets shift, jobs will inevitably follow. Others can judge better how Standard Life's intervention will affect voting intentions in Scotland. Viewed from outside, it seems incredible that a referendum can happen while the fundamental currency question is still up in the air.

webTitle: Inquiry into alleged GlaxoSmithKline bribery in China has led to pay fudge

fields.bodyText: GlaxoSmithKline had a terrific 2013 apart from one incident that has the potential to damage the company severely in its most important emerging market. The big issue, of course, is the allegation that the Chinese division was engaged in rampant bribery of local doctors. Eight months after Chinese police raided GSK's offices in the country, details of the alleged fraudulent behaviour are still in short supply. The Chinese authorities haven't yet presented their allegations and GSK's own investigation, commissioned from law firm Ropes and Gray, hasn't yet reported. So it's hard to know if we're looking at a tale of a few corrupt employees executing a sophisticated internal scam that could not possibly have been detected by head office; or whether the real scandal is lax oversight by GSK in the UK and poor audit systems, failings that could rightly be blamed on the top brass. In the circumstances, GSK's pay committee faced a tricky problem when determining boardroom bonuses for 2013. If the Chinese affair is a big scandal that should have been detected and will undermine GSK's long-term ambitions in China, why pay any bonuses to executives? If it's a more modest tale, then, yes, it would be hard to ignore GSK's strong performance in drug-discovery, profits and cash generation last year. The committee cannot be said to have risen to the challenge. The Chinese investigation was considered "at Sir Andrew's request", says the remuneration report, suggesting that pay chairman Tom de Swaan needed a prompt from chief executive Sir Andrew Witty himself. The eventual conclusion was a fudge. Bonuses were reduced slightly – Witty's bonus was cut by £243,000 but he still got £1.87m. This, shareholders are invited to think, shows GSK is "mindful of the impact this issue has had on the reputation of the company". But "reputation" is a woolly word in this context. Investors want to know if Witty and his senior colleagues, while clearly unaware of any Chinese shenanigans, should have known. If the answer is not yet clear, a common-sense remedy would be to defer bonuses until all the facts are in; alternatively, emphasise that payments will be clawed back if HQ is deemed at fault. De Swaan's stance looks confused. Given the seriousness of the allegations, that's not a message GSK should be sending.

webTitle: Bank of England identifies need to shelter homeowners from interest spike

fields.standfirst: Base rates are set to remain lower than the long run average to ensure that mortgage rates remain affordable
fields.body:
The Bank of England's base rate would peak close to 3% to protect mortgage payers from a big increase in monthly interest payments, a senior Bank of England official said .

David Miles, a member of the central bank's interest rate setting committee, said base rates would remain lower than the long run average to keep mortgage rates affordable. Banks would need to maintain a healthy margin between the cost of money charged by the Bank and the rates they charge customers unlike their policy in the boom years when lending margins could be wafer thin, he said.

In a speech at Leeds University Business School, Miles outlined how base rates had averaged about 5% since the Bank was founded in 1694. In the 1990s, mortgage rates were commonly 2.5-3 percentage points above the Bank's base rate but, in 2006 and 2007, that gap had fallen to only 0.5 percentage points or less. "The new normal for monetary policy will probably involve setting Bank rate on average at a lower level than before the crisis," he said.

Base rates are important because they set the benchmark for borrowing by high street lenders from the central bank. In the late 1990s, they peaked at 7.5% before falling to 3.5% in 2003 and were 4.5% to 4.75% throughout most of 2005 and 2006.

Even in the depths of the recession there was an expectation among most businesses and homeowners that rates would go back to the long run average following the economy's full recovery.

The message from most, if not all, policymakers is that to maintain margins on commercial and home loans of about 2 percentage points, base rates need to remain at or below 3%.

Mark Carney, the Bank governor, said this month in the quarterly inflation report that rates were likely to start rising next year and peak about 3%. He said it was the central bank's view that the UK economy would continue to underperform for several more year.

Miles said the fear of another crash would encourage investors to favour UK government bonds over other assets, driving down the market interest rate.

webTitle: Auditors' role in conflict gold trade | @guardianletters

fields.body:
The unregulated trade in gold is fuelling wars and brutal human rights abuses in places such as eastern Congo and Sudan, which is why it is important this story came to light (Confidential papers raise fears over conflict gold, 26 February). The actions of Ernst & Young and the Dubai regulator, while perfectly legal, undermine trust in the industry at a critical time.

In our view, the Dubai metals regulator, the Dubai Multi Commodities Centre (DMCC), could not have secured a clean audit result for a major gold player without Ernst & Young's willingness to turn a blind eye to the ethics involved. Auditors like Ernst & Young play a key role in assuring the public that companies are meeting important standards. If auditors can't be relied upon to put ethical principles above business interests, progress in cleaning up the global mineral trade will be jeopardised. Public disclosure is a major incentive to improving business practice. This case points to the need for stricter guidelines for conflict minerals audits to ensure that all findings – especially critical ones – see the light of day. There may also be a need to consider new rules for auditors to reduce the tension between safeguarding the public interest and promoting client or commercial concerns.

Global Witness is calling on Kaloti Jewellery International to immediately release its unpublished audit report, and is urging the government of Dubai to investigate any breaches of conduct by the DMCC. The authorities should also address the inherent conflict of interest in the DMCC's role both as a regulator and a promoter of trade.
Annie Dunnebacke
Deputy campaigns director, Global Witness

webTitle: RBS shares slump 8% on £8bn losses

fields.bodyText: Shares in Royal Bank of Scotland fell nearly 8% on Thursday, after the bailed-out bank posted a loss of more than £8bn – its sixth consecutive multi-billion loss since its 2008 taxpayer rescue. New chief executive Ross McEwan confirmed the bank was still paying out bonuses of £576m, despite the huge loss – to "keep people engaged" – and announced another major overhaul of its structure. But RBS also put the City on notice that it could be ready for a pre-election sale of part of the taxpayer's stake early next year. RBS and the government had hoped to sell a first batch of shares toward the end of this year but unexpected costs for settling litigation and regulatory disputes disrupted that plan. Sir Philip Hampton, RBS chairman, said: "All we can do is to put the bank back in a state where we can write a prospectus, so there is a reasonable amount of clarity. I think we will have much more clarity by the time we get into 2015." The eventual timing of any sale would be up to the government, he added. The taxpayer owns 81% of RBS after investing £45bn in its shares to prevent the bank collapsing at the peak of the financial crisis in 2008. Selling the first tranche of shares before next May's election would let the chancellor boast he was on the road to getting money back from both bank rescues. Lloyds Banking Group, also bailed out in the crisis, is preparing for a sale of the government's remaining 33% stake this year. RBS's £3.8bn of costs for litigation, fines and compliance and £4.8bn of losses on troubled assets contributed to the vast £8.24bn annual loss – more than £22m a day. However, RBS intends to pay £576m in staff bonuses for last year. The bonus pool is down 15% from 2012, and only £2,000 per person will be paid out in cash with the rest in deferred shares – but the decision revived uproar over pay at a bank kept afloat by taxpayers. Vince Cable, the business secretary, said: "The public will simply not understand why big bonuses and large salaries continue to be paid out by a loss-making public enterprise, still under-performing in many areas." He added: "If RBS is to become the sensible, boring bank envisaged by the chief executive, the bonus culture will have to go." McEwan acknowledged that the bonus figure was "highly emotional" but insisted he needed to hold on to his best people to revive RBS, which owns NatWest and Ulster Bank. "I need to pay these people fairly in the marketplace to do the job," he said. Bankers' bonuses continue to plague the industry. Barclays increased bonuses by 10% last week to £2.4bn. HSBC said on Monday it would increase salaries for bosses to get around an EU bonus cap. McEwan, who has turned down his bonus for 2013, declined to say whether RBS would ask shareholders, including the government, for permission to circumvent the EU cap this year. "The board has not opined," he said. RBS shares fell 7.74% to 326.6p, wiping more than £3bn off its market value. It now has a stock market value of £37bn. RBS had warned last month that its pretax loss would be about £8bn but investors were unnerved by an operating loss of £2.3bn – worse than the £1.7bn analysts expected. Ian Gordon, banks analyst at Investec, said: "We currently see no relative or absolute support for RBS's 'frothy' valuation; a correction is due. Sell." McEwan, who took over in October after Stephen Hester was forced out by the chancellor, George Osborne, said RBS had lost touch with its customers before the financial crisis and had to repair the damage. He described RBS as "the least trusted bank in the least trusted sector in the marketplace." His new plans to revitalise the business include: • Refocusing on UK rather than global customers – to increase the share of total assets from Britain from 60% to 80%. • Shrinking RBS from seven businesses into three: personal and business banking, commercial and private banking, and corporate and institutional banking. • Simplifying products for retail and small business customers, including scrapping "teaser rates" and 0% credit card transfers. He said it was "abhorrent" that new customers got a better deal than longstanding clients and said customers hated such schemes. • Cutting costs because the bank is "too expensive and too bureaucratic". McEwan's plan will cut out large swaths of head office and administrative staff. Declining to put a figure on potential job cuts, he also said that RBS – which employs 120,000 people – could scrap more businesses that customers did not need. The bank has already quit equity capital markets, mergers and acquisitions and structured finance. McEwan refused to be drawn on RBS's plans for a possible yes vote to Scottish independence in September, saying: "This is an issue for Scotland. The people have to decide and the governments will agree and we need to be thinking about the plans around that." By contrast, Standard Life said on Thursday it was working on contingency plans to move its base from Edinburgh to London if Scotland leaves the UK. McEwan's neutrality was compromised by an assessment of the consequences of independence on page 140 of the results that warned a yes vote for a separate Scotland "would be likely to significantly impact the group's credit ratings and could also impact the fiscal, monetary, legal and regulatory landscape to which the group is subject." Commenting on the results and the restructuring, a Treasury spokesperson said: "The chancellor said last year that he wanted RBS to be a bank that is focused on lending to British businesses and families. The plan, announced by Ross McEwan and the board today, delivers that vision."

webTitle: Lego builds yet another record profit to become world's top toymaker

fields.standfirst: The Danish toy company has overtaken rival Mattel after 'an incredible quadrupling of revenues in less than 10 years'
fields.body:
It is a brand name familiar to children around the world, but a decade ago Lego was in crisis. Sales were collapsing at a rate of 26% a year, it lost 1.4bn Danish kroner (£150m) in 2003 and private equity firms were circling the 82-year-old family-owned Danish company.

Now, after a series of job cuts and the ending of the family's management of the company, the plastic brick business has rebuilt itself into the world's most profitable toy maker ahead of Barbie's Mattel.

The company, which has been headquartered in the small Danish town of Billund (population 6,155) since 1932, has reported "another record breaking year" of sales and profits growth – for the ninth consecutive year. Its high profitability comes from its ability to turn each kilogram of raw material plastic – which costs less than $1 – into sets that sell for more than $75 per kg.

Annual profits increased by almost 10% to 8.2bn kroner (£900m) – about the same as the profit Facebook turned in last year. Sales jumped 10% to 25.3bn kroner (£2.8bn).

"That is an incredible quadrupling of our revenues in less than 10 years," Joergen Vig Knudstorp, Lego chief executive, said. "We think we are changing children's lives forever when they play with Lego. We think this was another year where we got great affirmation of that."

Knudstorp is credited with driving Lego's resurgence since he took over as CEO from Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen, grandson of the company's carpenter founder, during the 2003-4 crisis.

He said Lego's success was due to constant innovation and the creation of 60-70 new products every year, including Harry Potter, Star Wars and SpongeBob SquarePants ranges. But he admitted it is still a "major innovation challenge" to "stay on the top of children's wish lists" against competition from iPads and computer games. "We need to constantly become better, or otherwise there will be someone out there who will catch up to us," he said.

Jane Westgarth, a toy analyst at market research firm Mintel, said Lego's recovery had been fuelled by its investment in quality and design. "They are doing things that are taking Lego into a slightly different position, from the boxes of bricks where you had to use your imagination to sets you use in specific ways with characters you already know," she said. "If it's good quality, people are prepared to pay that little bit extra."

Westgarth said Lego was also benefiting considerably from parents' nostalgia for their own childhood – parents including David Beckham, who admitted earlier this month that he builds Lego with his children to stay calm and had just completed the 4,287-piece Tower Bridge kit. "For a parent aged 30 there's no doubt about it that they would have Lego in their homes. Parents like to introduce their children to things that they loved as children."

The company, which sold its Legoland theme parks to Madame Tussauds owner Merlin Entertainments in 2005, is building on its "red core business" by boosting its digital presence, but Knudstorp said his customers have done most of the work for him.

More than 99% of Lego videos on Youtube – featuring Lego recreations of everything from the London 2012 Olympics to the New Testament – are made by users. "We're not leaving the brick, but we will leverage digital technology to stay relevant over the next 20 years," he said.

Lego, which is derived from the Danish "leg godt" meaning "play well", is also benefiting from "a considerable amount of excitement" prompted by the Lego Movie. The film, which features the hit Tegan and Sara song Everything is Awesome, is taking £2m a day in UK cinema box offices, and has topped the US and Canadian charts for three consecutive weekends.

Next up is Knudstorp's "pretty simple ambition" to "take the bricks all over the world". Lego is sold in more than 130 countries round the world, but Knudstorp admits that "we're not really there" in many of the world's less well off nations.

"We see a huge opportunity to bring Lego further out into the world in the next 20 years," he said.

Sales in China, where Lego will open a new $300m factory in 2016, grew by more than 50% last year - although from asmall base. Knudstorp believes Lego could be expanded to 600m Chinese customers within in the next decade."But we need a set up that is much more diverse, much more international, than we are today.

"It would be arrogant to think that just because you're Danish you're equally knowledgeable about what it takes to succeed in countries all over the world," he said. "We want to remain very much a Danish company rooted here in Billund, a place where we were born and we have our heritage and we will never leave.

"But we want to be a Danish company that's welcoming to all sorts of cultures."

To do so the company is diversifying senior management into four global offices in London, Singapore, Shanghai and Connecticut.

The company is still owned by the descendents of Ole Kirk Kristiansen, a master carpenter and joiner who founded the company in Billund in 1932, when it was a small village. Ole's son Godtfred joined the firm when he was 12 years old, and the company's first toy was a wooden duck called Lego. The first plastic bricks were produced in 1949.

Godtfred's son Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen was chief executive from 1979-2004. Forbes magazine named Kjeld as Denmark's richest man with a net worth of $7.3bn in March 2013. A spokeswoman declined to comment on the family's current wealth.

He said Lego's success was due to constant innovation and the creation of 60-70 new products every year, including Harry Potter, Star Wars and SpongeBob SquarePants ranges. But he admitted it is still a "major innovation challenge" to "stay on the top of children's wish lists" against competition from iPads and computer games. "We need to constantly become better, or otherwise there will be someone out there who will catch up to us," he said. Jane Westgarth, a toy analyst at market research firm Mintel, said Lego's recovery had been fuelled by its investment in quality and design. "They are doing things that are taking Lego into a slightly different position, from the boxes of bricks where you had to use your imagination to sets you use in specific ways with characters you already know," she said. "If it's good quality, people are prepared to pay that little bit extra." Westgarth said Lego was also benefiting considerably from parents' nostalgia for their own childhood – parents including David Beckham, who admitted earlier this month that he builds Lego with his children to stay calm and had just completed the 4,287-piece Tower Bridge kit. "For a parent aged 30 there's no doubt about it that they would have Lego in their homes. Parents like to introduce their children to things that they loved as children." The company, which sold its Legoland theme parks to Madame Tussauds owner Merlin Entertainments in 2005, is building on its "red core business" by boosting its digital presence, but Knudstorp said his customers have done most of the work for him. More than 99% of Lego videos on Youtube – featuring Lego recreations of everything from the London 2012 Olympics to the New Testament – are made by users. "We're not leaving the brick, but we will leverage digital technology to stay relevant over the next 20 years," he said. Lego, which is derived from the Danish "leg godt" meaning "play well", is also benefiting from "a considerable amount of excitement" prompted by the Lego Movie. The film, which features the hit Tegan and Sara song Everything is Awesome, is taking £2m a day in UK cinema box offices, and has topped the US and Canadian charts for three consecutive weekends. Next up is Knudstorp's "pretty simple ambition" to "take the bricks all over the world". Lego is sold in more than 130 countries round the world, but Knudstorp admits that "we're not really there" in many of the world's less well off nations. "We see a huge opportunity to bring Lego further out into the world in the next 20 years," he said. Sales in China, where Lego will open a new $300m factory in 2016, grew by more than 50% last year - although from asmall base. Knudstorp believes Lego could be expanded to 600m Chinese customers within in the next decade."But we need a set up that is much more diverse, much more international, than we are today. "It would be arrogant to think that just because you're Danish you're equally knowledgeable about what it takes to succeed in countries all over the world," he said. "We want to remain very much a Danish company rooted here in Billund, a place where we were born and we have our heritage and we will never leave. "But we want to be a Danish company that's welcoming to all sorts of cultures." To do so the company is diversifying senior management into four global offices in London, Singapore, Shanghai and Connecticut. The company is still owned by the descendents of Ole Kirk Kristiansen, a master carpenter and joiner who founded the company in Billund in 1932, when it was a small village. Ole's son Godtfred joined the firm when he was 12 years old, and the company's first toy was a wooden duck called Lego. The first plastic bricks were produced in 1949. Godtfred's son Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen was chief executive from 1979-2004. Forbes magazine named Kjeld as Denmark's richest man with a net worth of $7.3bn in March 2013. A spokeswoman declined to comment on the family's current wealth.

fields.trailText: The Danish toy company has overtaken rival Mattel after 'an incredible quadrupling of revenues in less than 10 years'

webTitle: AO World's flotation sparks bumper payout for firm's bankers

fields.standfirst: Rothschild among financial firms to share pot worth up to £29m after dotcom-era-like flotation of online appliance retailer
fields.body:
AO World, the online appliance seller, cooked up a cash bonanza of up to £29m for bankers when the website floated on the stockmarket this week.

Rothschild, AO's main financial adviser in the run up to the flotation, will make £12m in fees, or 1% of the company's initial market capitalisation, and could also receive a further £500,000 "at the company's discretion," according to the prospectus released late on Wednesday.

Meanwhile, JP Morgan, Jefferies International and Numis Securities, which all acted as underwriters to the float, will share about £10.6m. They could also get a further £4.2m at AO's discretion.

JP Morgan also has a chance to earn a further £1.56m fee as the bank arranged a so-called "green shoe" offer. This will be triggered if there is strong enough demand for the stock and would mean a further 22m shares being put on the market.

The bankers' payments dwarf the company's £8.7m pre-tax profits in the year to March 31 2013, as analysts said the ratio of AO's valuation to its earnings was reminiscent of the dotcom boom. Back when the potential for the internet was first spotted in the late 1990s, technology company valuations soared before crashing when the bubble burst in 2001.

AO achieved a bumper market capitalisation of £1.2bn on Wednesday, four times the valuation bankers put on the company only last year. The shares soared in initial trading from the launch price of 285p to 378p, valuing the company at £1.6bn at close of play on Wednesday. On Thursday the shares slid 2.9% as a sense of reality began to return, wiping nearly £50m off its value.

Independent retail analyst Nick Bubb said AO's initial valuation was "somewhat excessive". He added: "AO's excellent customer service has clearly excited investors, but AO has yet to prove that its recent UK success (following the demise of Comet) is sustainable."

The excitement over AO matches the fervour around online fashion retailer Asos and online grocer Ocado, both of which have seen their valuations climb to new heights in the last year.

John Roberts, the former kitchen salesman who founded and still leads AO, made £86m from selling some of his shares in the business ahead of the flotation and still holds a stake worth more than £408m.

But analysis of the prospectus reveals that Roberts and his fellow shareholders had already split £2.8m in dividends last year, as they took the first payout from the company in at least three years.

Roberts, who owned about 38% of the company's shares before the flotation, would have taken home just over £1m of that dividend payment even as he prepared to hand the company over to the public markets. The founder, who has committed to staying with the company, said last month: "We are not taking profits and running for the hills or refinancing our balance sheet to pay off debts."

However, the payouts to founder shareholders and their advisers are likely to lead to heavy exceptional costs on AO's maiden results announcement this spring.

They also set the bar for a longed-for revival in bankers' fees as a string of retailers head for the stockmarket in the next few months. While convenience store group McColl's only managed a valuation slightly lower than it had hoped for when it joined the market this week, online fashion retailer Boohoo.com, specialist retailer Pets at Home and discounter Poundland are all expected to be embraced by the stock market in the next few weeks.

As many as 15 retailers, including B&M, Fat Face and House of Fraser are also looking at joining the market.

webTitle: Cyprus parliament rejects privatisation plan demanded by lenders -- as it happened

fields.standfirst:
AP: Bailout thrown into doubt

Cyprus MPs reject privatisation plan - coverage starts here.

Photos: protests outside parliament

Closing summary
fields.body:
8.00pm GMT

Closing summary

That’s all for tonight. To recap:

Cyprus’s bailout programme has been thrown into uncertainty after MPs failed to support a plan to privatise three state assets.

Tonight, the parliament voted 25-25 (with five abstentions) on whether to sell off the country’s electricity provider, telecoms operator and ports authority.

The privatisation is part of Cyprus’s bailout plan -- without it, the country may not receive its next aid tranche. A second vote could be held next week.

The rejection came as hundreds of striking workers protested outside the Nicosia parliament, saying the selloff would be a disaster for Cyprus. Latest photos here.

The news came at the end of a busy day.....

Royal Bank of Scotland shares have slumped 7.75% after reporting a £8.2bn loss at 7am, and unveiling its new strategic plan

Analysts said the company is still dealing with the legacy of Fred Goodwin...

...and dogged by fears that it needs to raise more capital.

This earlier summary gives more details of RBS’s results, its strategic plan, and the row over the bank’s £576m bonus payouts.

While in America, Fed chair Janet Yellen said the US central bank is watching closely to see whether recent ‘soft’ economic data is due to the bad weather.

Thanks, and goodnight. GW

7.49pm GMT

7.39pm GMT

Associated Press just published a good take on the situation:

Cyprus Parliament Turns Down Privatization Bill

Cyprus’ lawmakers on Thursday effectively forced the government to renegotiate terms of legislation that would pave the way for the privatization of state-owned companies, a condition of the debt-laden country’s rescue deal with international lenders.

The vote throws into doubt whether Cyprus will receive the next batch of bailout money that the government said is necessary to stave off bankruptcy.

The country has until March 5 to pass the legislation which several parties including left-wing AKEL and socialist EDEK had staunchly opposed.

Lawmakers voted 25 in favor, 25 against and five abstained. The tie meant the legislation was turned down.

“We must now deal with what happens next with the rescue program,” Prodromos Prodormou, spokesman for the ruling right-wing Democratic Rally Party, told state broadcaster CyBC.

EDEK lawmaker George Varnava said it’s up to the government to renegotiate the bill with international lenders.

AKEL leader Andros Kyprianou told parliament before the vote that his party would not consent to the “sell off of the nation’s wealth” and denounced what he called the “blackmail” of international lenders.

“We have warned for months now that we would reject this legislation,” Kyprianou told CyBC, adding that the government should enter into dialogue with parties on alternatives.

Cyprus government spokesman Christos Stylianides warned earlier Thursday that rejection of the bill would risk pushing the country into bankruptcy in the next couple of months.

Hundreds of people had gathered outside parliament to protest against the bill. Barricades police in full riot gear prevented protesters from nearing the parliament’s entrance.

7.25pm GMT

Photos: Cyprus protests

More photos from the demonstrations outside the parliament, led by striking electricity workers who urged MPs to oppose the privatisation plan:

7.11pm GMT

George Iordanou, a PhD student and Cyprus expert, explains that the Nicosia government can’t simply bring the same legislation back next week - changes will be needed.

7.09pm GMT

The Cypriot parliament is developing quite a reputation: eleven months ago, it sensationally voted down the original bailout terms (under which all bank accounts were tapped), forcing a rethink.

6.57pm GMT

To recap, the bill rejected tonight would have cleared the way to sell three state-owned bodies: Cyprus Telecoms, the Electricity Authority and the Cyprus Ports Authority, raising perhaps €1.4bn by 2018.

The next tranche of Cyprus’s aid package, worth €236m, was due to be paid in March -- but only if the privatisation bill was passed.

Updated at 7.00pm GMT

6.54pm GMT

Cyprus Mail: Second vote may come next week

The Cyprus Mail confirms that tonight’s vote on whether or not to approve the privatisation plan demanded by the country’s troika of lenders was extremely close:

Parliament on Thursday night rejected the bill designed to pave the way for the privatisation of semi-government organisations, telecoms company CyTA, the electricity authority EAC and the Cyprus Ports Authority.

The vote went 25 in favour, 25 against and five abstentions.

To pass, it needed a majority vote in favour. It is possible a new bill will be submitted before the Eurogroup meets on March 5, the date they were due to give the go ahead for the fourth tranche of bailout aid, which is now uncertain.

(more protest photos here)

6.35pm GMT

Eurozone crisis experts reckon Cyprus will cut a deal to get the privatisation deal though:

Still, it’s another reminder that while the eurozone is calmer, the crisis is not played out.

Updated at 7.44pm GMT

6.25pm GMT

Reuters: Cyprus parliament rejects privatisation plan sought by lenders

Here’s Reuters’ first take on the Cyprus privatisation vote:

Cyprus’s parliament on Thursday rejected a privatisation plan that is necessary for the island to receive a new tranche of international aid.

In a cliffhanger vote, 25 lawmakers rejected the bill, 25 approved it and there were five abstentions.

Approval of the privatisations is mandatory under terms of a €10bn bailout the island secured a year ago, and for the fourth tranche of aid in March.

6.22pm GMT

Cyprus parliament rejects privatisation bill

Some late breaking news from Cyprus -- the Nicosia parliament has just rejected the privatisation bill that was debated today.

That bill, as explained at 3.37pm, paved the way to sell off various state assets including its electricity supplier. That’s a key demand of the country’s lenders.

A defeat looked highly possible after one of the government’s junior coalition partners withdrew earlier today.

From Cyprus, George Markides flags up that the bill could be voted on again next week:

6.07pm GMT

A late newsflash from Madrid:

27-Feb-2014 18:01 - SPAIN STARTS PLACING OF 7.5% OF BANKIA THROUGH ACCELERATED BOOK BUILD THROUGH MORGAN STANLEY, UBS AND DEUTSCHE SAYS UBS

6.07pm GMT

Another photo from the demo outside the Cyprus parliament:

5.35pm GMT

In case you’re trying to catch up - here’s the official lines from RBS:

5.30pm GMT

City analyst Louise Cooper pins the blame for RBS’s £8.2bn annual loss firmly at the door of the man who ran it until the financial criss struck:

RBS reported a worse than expected £8.2bn of pre-tax loss for 2013, mainly due to the corruption and incompetence of Fred Goodwin’s days in charge. £3.8bn was the cost of fines and customer compensation – the corruption. And a massive £8.4bn charge was for loan losses –the incompetence - half of which are still from the Irish Ulster Bank.

Both these are legacy issues from Fred the Shred’s time – paying the costs of illegal behaviour and the results of a poor quality loan book created under the anybody-can-get-a-loan-from-Fred-days.

She also points out that RBS’s report was bulked out with cautionary warnings of future legal risks:

In detail the £3.8bn was made up of £900mn PPI, £550mn Interest rate hedging and £2.4bn fines and legal costs. But however it is made up, all the way through the clean-up, the costs of past filth have been greater than analysts and the banks have expected. Most are now forecasting the worst is over but note RBS had 16 pages of litigation and threats in its annual results statement (HSBC only had six pages – so in one area at least RBS is overachieving relative to its peers - the number of pages of naughtiness!).

5.14pm GMT

Fears that RBS will need to raise more funds to hit its capital reserve requirements helped to drive its shares down so sharply today, explains Michael Hewson of CMC Markets:

The biggest faller today has been Royal Bank of Scotland after the bailed out bank confirmed losses of £8.2bn, as well as announcing plans to restructure the existing business into three separate divisions.

Today’s losses weren’t that surprising, given that they were flagged several weeks ago, but there is a concern that the bank will have to raise extra capital by further disbursements, including its US operation Citizens Bank, as well as the extra branches it has been trying to sell for the past two years.

Updated at 5.22pm GMT

5.04pm GMT

4.45pm GMT

£3bn wiped off RBS's market cap

More than £3bn has been wiped off the value of Royal Bank of Scotland, as the City gives its verdict to the company’s £8.2bn loss and strategic plan.

Shares in Royal Bank of Scotland have closed down 7.74%, losing 27.4p to 326.6p.

That means the company is worth almost £37bn, down from just over £40bn last night.

Updated at 5.00pm GMT

4.26pm GMT

Another photo from the anti-privatisation protests in Cyprus (3.37pm onwards)

4.08pm GMT

Janet Yellen testifies to Senate Banking Committee - highlights

Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen has said that recent disappointing economic data is probably partly due to the icy weather that struck America over the winter, but she’s watching closely to see whether the US recovery is on track.

Asked about recent softness in economic data, Yellen told the Senate Banking Committee that

Since my appearance before the House committee [on 11 February], a number of data releases have pointed to softer spending than many analysts have expected.

Part of that softness may reflect adverse weather conditions, but at this point it’s difficult to discern exactly how much. In the weeks and months ahead, my colleagues and I will be attentive to signals that indicate whether the recovery is progressing in line with our earlier expectations.

(Yellen’s appearance had itself been delayed by two weeks because of heavy snow in Washington).

Yellen also told Senators that monetary policy will remain accommodative for “quite some time”:

“There’s no conflict at all at the moment between the two goals the Congress has assigned to us of promoting maximum employment and price stability.”

She cautioned that “fiscal drag” had held back growth:

Fiscal policy really has been quite tight and has imposed a substantial drag on spending in the U.S. economy over the last several years.

And struck a positive note about the US recovery:

“I do think the economy is beginning to recover and we have made progress. And in the minimum, I would hope fiscal policy would do no harm.”

Updated at 4.15pm GMT

3.51pm GMT

3.49pm GMT

And here’s AP’s take on the protests in Cyprus:

Hundreds of protesters have gathered outside Cyprus’ parliament to voice opposition against legislation that will pave the way for the privatization of state-owned companies.

Barricades and a cordon of police in full riot gear have blocked off the street leading to parliament where lawmakers will vote on the bill later Thursday.

Among the protesters are workers from Cyprus’ electricity, telecommunications and ports authorities which have been earmarked for privatization.

Privatizations are a condition of Cyprus’ 10 billion euro ($13.66 billion) rescue package that the country agreed with international lenders last year.

The legislation is a prerequisite for Cyprus to receive the next batch of bailout money that the government said is needed to stave off bankruptcy.

Lawmakers have introduced amendments to the legislation to protect workers’ jobs and pension benefits.

3.37pm GMT

Protests in Cyprus over privatisations

In Cyprus, hundreds of protesters massed outside the parliament building in Nicosia, in a face off with riot police.

Reuters reports that they chanted “hands off”, as MPs prepared to debate the privatisation of state assets, a key part of its bailout programme.

The plan would see Cyprus’s Ports Authority, telecoms operator and electricity authority, EAC, all sold off.

EAC union leader Andreas Panorkos warned:

“This bill will be devastating for the organisation, it will turn it into a private monopoly,”

The protests come as one of the government’s coalition parties quits. That leaves the ruling Democratic Rally party, and another ally, controlling just 21 seats in the 56-member chamber

Labour unions have staged strikes this week, leading to rolling power cuts, in an attempt to block the privatisations. The government, though, says the plan must be agreed by early March to unlock the next tranche of loans.

2.47pm GMT

Summary: Anger over RBS bonuses and loss

Time to catch up.

Royal Bank of Scotland has posted its sixth annual loss in a row, losing £8.2bn after incurring heavy losses creating a bad bank and through litigation and PPI compensation.

CEO Ross McEwan said RBS needs to change (VIDEO), as he unveiled a new strategic plan to refocus on Britain. He vowed to clean up RBS’s image, and rebuild customer confidence.

But the decision to pay out over half a billion pounds in bonuses had reignited anger over City pay. Business secretary Vince Cable said the bonus culture had to stop, while Lib Dem Lord Oakeshott dubbed RBS the “Robber Baron Service”.

While a big loss was expected, analysts warned that the bank had performed worse than expected last year.

RBS shares have tumbled 8%, wiping around £3bn off its value.

The Ukraine crisis has sent shares down across Europe, with the main indices falling up to 1.3%, while the Ukrainian Hryvnia hit a fresh record low.

Standard Life has threatened to move its HQ out of Edinburgh if Scotland votes for independence. The CBI said the warning shows the depth of concern over the Scottish referendum, but first minister Alex Salmond dismissed the warning.

S&P said an independent Scotland would face challenges but not insumountable ones

Lego has posted a 10% jump in revenues for last year -- thanks to strong demand to new brands and traditional offerings.

2.25pm GMT

Scotland’s first minister, Alex Salmond, robustly rejected Standard Life’s concerns -- telling the Holyrood assembly that the financial group would thrive after independence.

During first minister’s questions, Salmond said:

“My submission would be that Standard Life would find Scotland a good place to do business, as it does in 10 countries around the world.”

More here: Alex Salmond says Standard Life would prosper in independent Scotland

Updated at 2.45pm GMT

2.15pm GMT

The CBI has weighed in on Scottish independence, saying Standard Life’s worries are shared by many other firms:

John Cridland, CBI Director-General, said:

“Standard Life’s announcement that ‘it would take whatever action necessary to protect its business’ underlines the concerns felt by many successful Scotland-based firms.

“Faced with uncertainties around currency, the shape and role of the monetary system, the European Union, future taxation and regulation, businesses need evidence-based clarity from the Scottish Government so future jobs and competitiveness can be assured.”

1.55pm GMT

Cable lays into RBS over bonuses

RBS’s £576m bonus pot has now been criticised by Vince Cable, the business secretary, who said the culture of chunky bonuses must be swept away if the bank is serious about reform.

I’ve taken it from PA:

Business Secretary Vince Cable has led a chorus of criticism from across the political spectrum of RBS’s announcement that it will pay out £576 million in bonuses despite posting an £8.2 billion loss for the year.

Despite calls for bonuses to be curtailed, RBS chief executive Ross McEwan insisted the payments have a role to play in attracting and retaining the best staff.

Dr Cable said: “The public will simply not understand why big bonuses and large salaries continue to be paid out by a loss-making public enterprise, still under-performing in many areas.

“The smaller bonus pool is due to the bank’s US-based investment banking operations, which will soon be sold. If RBS is to become the sensible, boring bank envisaged by the CEO, the bonus culture will have to go.”

I mentioned earlier that Ross McEwan argued RBS must pay the going rate to its bankers, adding “ I do need to be in the market to get people to do these jobs.”

But former Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman Lord Oakeshott was dripping with sarcasm:

“They’ve lost £8.2bn of our money and they’ve paid £576m in bonuses - what on earth would they pay if they made a profit? What does RBS stand for - Robber Banking Service?

“That’s the economics of the mad house, no normal business making a thumping loss like this would pay out massive bonuses. Banking is just on another planet. Wherever you look, RBS is a total disaster.”

Updated at 1.57pm GMT

1.53pm GMT

Tyrie: Fundamental bonus reform is needed

Andrew Tyrie MP, the influential head of the Treasury Committee, makes an important point on Royal Bank of Scotland -- the people responsible for today’s losses cashed in their bonuses many years ago.

As flagged up earlier, setting up a bad bank cost RBS £4.8bn, while compensation, fines and legal costs wiped out another £3.8bn.

This shows why bank bonuses should be paid in shares, and help on a long leash - meaning they can be yanked back if problems emerge in future years, Tyrie argued.:

The losses today announced by RBS were partly caused by past misconduct and poor lending decisions.

“It is likely that many who took those decisions were rewarded for them. Their remuneration should have been subject to deferral and clawback - paying for their mistakes.

“Well after the crisis broke, bonus schemes have continued to reward failure. There are not enough signs that banks understand the need for radical reform of remuneration.

“RBS has introduced deferred bonuses for only up to three years. That will do little in many cases to match the rewards to the maturity of the risk.

“A fundamental reform of the bonus culture is needed. Much longer deferral and much greater scope for clawback, as recommended by the Banking Commission, are an essential part of that.

“Remuneration, and particularly bonuses, can be a powerful tool for higher standards. Well structured, they can incentivise better behaviour and prevent bankers receiving rewards until it is clear that they have been earned.”

Updated at 1.53pm GMT

1.44pm GMT

The Ukrainian currency, the Hryvnia, slumped to a new record low of 11 to the US dollar, after armed gunmen took control of government buildings in Crimea (our Ukraine liveblog has all the details)

Updated at 2.45pm GMT

1.15pm GMT

Market update

Royal Bank of Scotland’s tumbling share price has helped to knock the FTSE 100 into the red today, with the blue-chip index down 31 points, or 0.5%, at 6768.

RBS shares are currently down 8%, meaning £3.2bn has been knocked off its value today.

Toby Morris, senior sales trader at CMC Markets, sums up the mood:

RBS have been condemned to a 6th straight year of losses this morning, with the continued headwinds of restructuring and misconduct costs dwarfing the £2.5bln operating profit made elsewhere in the business.

Pre-tax losses where £8.2bn, and yet another set of horrendous numbers after years of rhetoric and numerous management shake ups seems to have run the patience of investors one step too far, who voted with their feet this morning, pushing the stock down to a firm last place in the FTSE.

Shares are down across Europe, as the Ukraine crisis continues to spook the markets.

  • German DAX: down 128 points at 9,533, -1.3%
  • French CAC: down 23 points at 4,373, -0.5%
  • Italian FTSE MIB: down 189 points at 20,208, -0.9%
  • Spanish IBEX: down 117 points at 10,106, -1.1%

12.50pm GMT

Speaking of the eurozone, Spain suffered a blow this morning with the news its economy grew less strongly than first thought.

Spanish GDP growth was revised down to +0.2% in the last quarter of 2014, down from +0.3%, raising fears that its recovery from recession may be faltering.

12.12pm GMT

Followers of our eurozone crisis: Angela Merkel is starting to address the UK parliament right now. Full coverage here:

Angela Merkel, the German chancellor, visits Britain: Politics live blog

12.11pm GMT

RBS has also warned today that its credit rating could be cut if Scotland declares independence -- which would push up its borrowing costs.

On page 140 of today’s report, it warns:

A vote in favour of Scottish independence would be likely to significantly impact the Group’s credit ratings and could also impact the fiscal, monetary, legal and regulatory landscape to which the Group is subject

11.55am GMT

S&P: Challenge for independent Scotland is "significant, but not unsurpassable"

Ratings agency Standard & Poor’s has waded into the debate over Scotland, saying that going it along would be a “significant” challenge, but not an impossible one.

S&P also declared that an independent Scotland would not probably suffer the ignominy of a ‘junk’ credit rating.

Here’s the key points:

  • STANDARD & POOR’S: EXPECT INDEPENDENT SCOTLAND TO BENEFIT FROM ALL THE ATTRIBUTES OF AN INVESTMENT-GRADE SOVEREIGN CREDIT CHARACTERISED BY ITS WEALTHY ECONOMY
  • STANDARD & POOR’S: INDEPENDENT SCOTLAND WOULD FACE COMPARATIVELY HIGH PUBLIC DEBT, SENSITIVITY TO OIL PRICES, POTENTIALLY LIMITED MONETARY FLEXIBILITY
  • STANDARD & POOR’S: INDEPENDENT SCOTLAND’S EXTERNAL POSITION FOR LIQUIDITY AND INVESTMENT COULD BE SUBJECT TO VOLATILITY SHOULD BANKS LEAVE
  • STANDARD & POOR’S: CHALLENGE FOR SCOTLAND TO GO IT ALONE WOULD BE SIGNIFICANT, BUT NOT UNSURPASSABLE

Interesting timing -- given Standard Life’s threat today to move its HQ out of Edinburgh....

Updated at 12.13pm GMT

11.32am GMT

The Bricks Economy: Lego sales jump 10%

All smiles at Lego today, as the toymaker posts another year of strong results and outpaced the market again.

Revenues surged by 10% as the company’s traditional ranges, and new offerings, proved popular with children. And with The Lego Movie now a box office hit, the Danish firm has staged a remarkable recovery since flirting with bankrupcy a decade ago.

Chief executive Joergen Vig Knudstorp declared that:

“In less than 10 years, we have now more than quadrupled our revenue.

In 2013 we successfully developed and launched products that children put high on their wish list all over the world.”

Lego posted double-digit growth in its “evergreen” product - such as DUPLO, the Technic and Creator range, and its Star Wars and City-themed products.

New brands did well too. Lego Friends -- launch in 2012 and targeted at girls -- had “shown its long term potential by also growing double digit in 2013”.

Legends of Chima (fantasy animals fighting over a power source) became a “major theme globally”, apparently.

Speaking to reporters, Knudstorp acknowledged that developing fresh themes and continuing to appeal to children is a “major challenge”, adding:

“With the level of growth we have right now we need to constantly think of expanding our facilities.”

Today’s annual report also shows that Lego hired another 1,355 staff last year, swelling its workforce by 13% to 11,755.

Lego is also expanding deeper into Asia, and building a factory in Jiaxing, China. When the factory opens in 2016, it will supply the growing Asian market with LEGO products, it said.

Sales rose to 25.38 billion kroner (£2.8bn), while net income increased 9 percent to 6.12 billion kroner (£700m).

Lego is a private company, so a small number of shareholders will reap the benefits - as the FT’s Richard Milne points out.

Finally, spare a thought for the lucky family and foundation shareholders that own Lego. It paid out a whopping DKr22m per share last year and is forecasting a payout of DKr24.4m [£2.7m] this year.

Shame the 205 shares in the company are so tightly held.

Many of those shares are owned by the family of carpenter Ole Kirk Christiansen, who founded the business back in 1932.

The full report is online here. (updated link).

Updated at 1.26pm GMT

11.19am GMT

Video: Ross McEwan pledges to maker RBS smaller and smarter

Speaking in London this morning, Ross McEwan was adamant that Royal Bank of Scotland’s global ambitions are consigned to history:

So let me spell it out very clearly: the days when RBS sought to be the biggest bank in the world - those days are well and truly over.

He also warned that RBS’s problems aren’t over:

Today won’t be the end of bad headlines. Past failures will continue to haunt us. But we can weather them.

Updated at 11.19am GMT

11.00am GMT

Plenty else going on today. Advertising group WPP has warned that its profit margins have been hit by currency fluctuations, sending its shares down over 5% despite posting a bigger jump in earnings than rivals.

10.47am GMT

The prospect of the UK government selling its 81% stake in Royal Bank of Scotland anytime soon is receding as quickly as its shares have tumbled.

Will Hedden of IG says many investors find Lloyds more attractive, especially given RBS’s grubby reputation:

It is still hard to see the light at the end of the tunnel of nationalisation as a sixth straight annual loss misses expectations and highlights the job that still remains. Further offloads will come later in the year, as the bank streamlines itself into a more traditional entity. One has to feel that the continued political fever created by bonus-paying at the investment bank has kept many investors away. Considering that since the beginning of 2013 RBS shares have barely moved, while Lloyds shares have gained more than 60%, you start to understand why the latter has been more popular with investors and traders alike.

We do not expect this to change in the medium-term, as the government stake and the frustration that this brings to taxpayers continues to cloud any investment potential.

10.25am GMT

Three billion pounds has been wiped off the value of RBS so far this morning, with shares down 7.5% at 327p.

Marc Kimsey, Senior Trader at Accendo Markets, says investors have been rushing to ditch RBS:

The selling pressure here this morning is immense, investors cannot get rid of their shares quick enough and traders are substantially adding to short positions. The latest update is a shocker - With the financial crisis so far behind us it is concerning to see company still in so much trouble. If you can give me a reason to buy, I’m all ears.

10.25am GMT

City firm Jeffries is also unimpressed by RBS’s financial performance, saying:

Core costs were well above our estimates and this was the disappointing angle today.

It cited the £4.8bn cost of creating a Bad Bank for legacy assets (Jeffries expected £4.5bn), adding:

Clean pre-tax profits of £1bn missed our estimate of £1.3bn driven by £200m cost miss and £100m worse impairments in UK corporate.

Updated at 10.36am GMT

10.16am GMT

Clegg: RBS bonuses need to keep coming down

Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg weighed in on the issue of RBS bonuses, saying it hasn’t earned the right to pay staff what it wants:

He told ITV1’s Daybreak:

“A loss-making bank that is basically on a life-support system because of the generosity of British taxpayers shouldn’t be dishing out ever larger amounts of money in pay and bonuses.

“The overall amount has been coming down. It needs to continue to come down. They are entitled to pay their staff what they want when they are standing on their own two feet. At the moment they are not.”

Important point -- RBS’s bonus pool may indeed have fallen 12% to £576m, but the total headcount is also lower.

Updated at 10.17am GMT

10.14am GMT

My colleague Hilary Osborne has analysed the changes announced by RBS today -- including its decision to end 0% ‘teaser’ rates to credit card customers who switch to it, and to abolish different rates to customers who bank online.

RBS outlines changes – what will that mean for its customers?

10.06am GMT

Charlotte Webster, campaign director of the Move Your Money campaign (which pushes for better banking) says RBS’s pledge to focus on Britain and improve customer service comes rather too late:

“We agree with Ross McEwan. The future of banking is with simple, small banks that can be trusted. But that’s not RBS, nor will that be anytime soon. This restructuring is long over due, with billions of pounds of spending cuts a direct result of years of malpractice.

But people are ahead of the game, we’re seeing millions of pounds move away from the big five banks to one of over 50 small and simple banks across the UK. 2.4 million people since 2012, and that’s set to escalate as the public realises just how simple it is to change banks or even explore new options like crowd funding. Our scorecard shows who’s performing best when it comes to customer service, ethics, contributing to the local economy and more. Yes, you guessed it, RBS came second from last.

From RBS we’re seeing too little far too late, and those with true local values are those that are winning.”

10.04am GMT

RBS - what the analysts say

RBS had been expected to make another large loss, but City analysts are warning that today’s results are weaker than ecpected.

Ian Gordon of Investec sums it up:

Revenues of £19.4bn, down £2.6bn (12%) year-on-year, were a £0.6bn (3%) miss vs consensus (£20.0bn). Costs of £13.3bn were £0.1bn (1%) worse than consensus. Impairments of £8.4bn were broadly in line, so taken together, the “underlying” Operating Loss of £2.3bn is a £0.6bn (35%) miss vs consensus.

Gordon has a Sell rating on the shares, predicting that “a correction is due” (and already underway, with the shares down 6% today).

He also provided these chart, showing how earnings from RBS’s “core” operations has shrunk since the crisis began -- partly due to the winding back of its investment banking, or Markets, division:

9.43am GMT

Some Twitter reaction to RBS’s results, and Standard Life’s threat to leave an independent Scotland:

9.39am GMT

The government, which controls almost 81% of RBS’s shares, has backed Ross McEwan’s turnaround plan:

The Chancellor said last year that he wanted RBS to be a bank that is focussed on lending to British businesses and families.

“The plan, announced by Ross McEwan and the Board today, delivers that vision and is further evidence of RBS’s new management getting to grips with the problems of the past and taking the bank in its new direction.”

9.34am GMT

The Robin Hood Tax Campaign, which is lobbying for a financial transactional tax, is also aghast to see more bonuses at RBS.

David Hillman said:

This beggars belief. In what other industry would a staff at a state owned company that helped bring the economy to its knees be lavishly rewarded for massive losses?

This is yet another example of one rule for the City another for the rest of us. It is time we made banks work in our interests rather than the other way around.

That, of course, is what Ross McEwan is promising - with his talk of rewarding customer loyalty, rebuilding trust and delivering a better service.

9.22am GMT

Labour: taxpayers will be incredulous

The opposition Labour party has slammed RBS for paying over half a billion pounds in bonuses after recording its sixth annual loss in a row in 2013.

Chris Leslie MP, Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury said:

“Taxpayers will be incredulous that such large bonuses continue to be paid out at a time when huge losses are being made.

“It’s vital that RBS starts to serve the British economy better and that we ensure taxpayers get their money back, so we are encouraged by the new longer-term strategy set out by Ross McEwan today.

Leslie also urged the government not to allow bonus payments of more than 100% base salary for the 2014 financial year. (Under EU rules, future bonuses can only be 200% of basic pay if shareholders agree).

“With bumper bonuses across a number of banks this year the government should now repeat Labour’s successful tax on bank bonuses. George Osborne should also make clear now that he would reject any request from RBS later this year for approval to pay bonuses of more than 100 per cent of salary.

At a time when ordinary families are facing a cost-of-living crisis and bank lending to business is down it cannot be justified.”

9.15am GMT

RBS also cited the Scottish independence vote as a potential threat to its business.

Its chairman, Sir Philip Hampton, told reporters:

Clearly there are issues we are looking at – currency, the application of financial regulation, lender of last resort, credit ratings – which could affect us

But there is real uncertainty about how any of these matters would be settled in the event of a ‘Yes’ vote and the outcome would depend on negotiations between the two governments.

9.10am GMT

Standard Life could quit Scotland if it votes for independence

The other big City news of the morning is that Standard Life, the pensions and savings firm, has revealed it is drawing up contingency plans to quit Scotland if it becomes an independent country.

Chairman Gerry Grimstone said the firm hopes to stay in Edinburgh, where it has been based for 189 years, but warned:

“We very much hope that this can continue.

But if anything were to threaten this, we will take whatever action we consider necessary – including transferring parts of our operations from Scotland – in order to ensure continuity and to protect the interests of our stakeholders.”

The firm is worried about the uncertainty that a Yes vote would create -- including what currency Scotland would use, its future monetary system, regulation, and fiscal policy.ld be able to join the European Union by the Scottish government’s preferred March 2016 target date.

Chief executive, David Nish, says the company has already begun registering new firms in England, as it waits for clarity on those issues.

Here’s the full story: Standard Life could quit Scotland if voters back independence

8.47am GMT

Here’s three key points from McEwan’s turnaround plan to regain the trust of the public and RBS’s customers:

  • Shrinking RBS from seven businesses into three: personal and business banking, commercial and private banking, and corporate and institutional banking.
  • Simplifying products for retail and small business customers, including scrapping “teaser rates” and 0% credit card transfers.
  • Cutting costs because the bank is “too expensive and too bureaucratic”.

And here’s Sean Farrell’s news story on Royal Bank of Scotland, which will be updated through the day.

Updated at 8.47am GMT

8.36am GMT

RBS shares continue to fall as City analysts chew through the meat of today’s statement -- now down 6.3% at 331.49p.

8.35am GMT

Richard Hunter, Head of Equities at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers, points out that RBS is still trying to fix the mistakes made before the collapse of Lehman Brothers:

“The numbers make for grim reading as RBS continues to wrestle with the legacy of its troubled past.

Many of the bank’s targets are some years away, and in the meantime the overall loss is greater than had been expected, even after RBS had taken some of the sting out of the news with its pre-release announcement in late January.

And while RBS’s staff will share £576m in bonuses, there’s nothing for shareholders, Hunter adds:

Group income fell 10%, the cost base is high, leading to a cost income ratio of 73%, and the planned divestments of Citizens and Williams & Glyn will provide further distractions. Meanwhile, the lack of a dividend payment and the sheer complexity of a restructure which will result in further elevated costs for the next two years are not positive for the investment case.

There are some glimmers of light within the statement, such as a reasonable capital cushion, improving credit quality, an operating profit and a simplification of the group which should benefit the bank in due course.

8.30am GMT

Veteran city analyst David Buik (who can normally be relied on to give the banks a fair hearing) says RBS has issued “awful numbers” today.

On the bonuses, he reckons:

The bonus pool of £576 million is unpalatable but very necessary to mitigate losses whilst the bank is in transition, in changing its culture from global international bank to domestic ‘Boring Bank PLC!’ – [which is] what the majority of the people in this country and the politicians want.

8.13am GMT

Shares in Royal Bank of Scotland have fallen 4.4% at the start of trading in London, down 15.7p to 338.3p.

Updated at 8.27am GMT

8.11am GMT

RBS CEO: We need to change

Ross McEwan told City reporters that today’s loss shows that RBS needs to change its ways, as he outlined a new plan to focus on Britain

On this morning’s conference call, he declared:

“Let’s be quite clear. We are too expensive, we are too bureacratic and we need to change.”

McEwan also defended the £576m set aside for bonuses, with the familiar argument that RBS is paying the market rate to retain staff.

Sean Farrell tweeted the key points:

McEwan only took over at RBS in October last year (promoted from running its retail arm), and has already waived his bonus for 2013 and 2014.

The heavy losses suffered by RBS since 2008 came under Stephen Hester’s management. But they were caused by the global ambitions of his predecessor - Fred ‘the Shred’ Goodwin - which were crushed by the financial crisis.

Updated at 8.19am GMT

8.10am GMT

RBS's legacy conduct issues

RBS also set aside regulatory and redress provisions of £3.8bn to cover “legacy conduct issues”.

In plain English, that’s the fines and compensation set aside to cover its role in the sub-prime mortgage scandal in the US, the payment protection mis-selling scandal, and the “interest rate hedging” scandal.

Here are the details:

● As announced in a trading update on 27 January 2014, RBS has provided £1,910 million in Q4 2013 covering claims and conduct-related matters primarily relating to mortgage-backed and other securities litigation. Regulatory and litigation provisions for the full year amounted to £2,394 million.

● An additional £465 million provision for Payment Protection Insurance (PPI) redress and related costs was booked in Q4 2013, making a total of £900 million for the full year 2013. Out of a cumulative PPI provision of £3.1 billion, £2.2 billion had been utilised by 31 December 2013. The remaining £0.9 billion provision covers approximately 12 months at current levels of redress and administrative expenses.

● A further £500 million provision was made in Q4 2013 for interest rate hedging products redress and administration costs, reflecting higher volumes, higher anticipated redress payments and recalibration of our methodology based on more recent trends. The total charge for the full year was £550 million making a total of £1.25 billion of which £0.2 billion had been utilised by 31 December 2013.

Updated at 8.10am GMT

8.04am GMT

More than half of RBS’s £8.2bn loss came from legacy bad debts --it recorded a loss of £4.823bn for creating a “bad bank” called RCR where it stashed toxic assets.

Updated at 8.04am GMT

7.50am GMT

RBS: A new strategy based on customer trust

RBS CEO Ross McEwan has declared that he wants to make RBS the most trusted bank in the UK by 2020, with a new focus on its customers.

In his message to shareholders, he declares:

We now have a strategy to deliver a sustainable bank with a clear ambition: we want to be number one for customer service, trust and advocacy, in every one of our chosen business areas by 2020.

To do this, RBS will be restructured to form a “highly effective” bank, so that it is “ structured around the needs of its customers” (whose interests is it revolving around today, Ross?). Seven existing operating divisions are being realigned into three businesses: Personal & Business Banking, Commercial & Private Banking and Corporate & Institutional Banking.

Today, only 30% of RBS staff actually deal directly with customers -- that will be hiked to 50% by 2017 under McEwan’s strategic review.

And he also warned he won’t hesitate to swing the axe:

For those activities where we can’t see a clear path to being number one, we will review on the basis of ‘fix, close or dispose’. These will become clear as each of our three businesses defines its new customer franchises over the coming months.

You can see the results on the London Stock Exchange website (pdf).

Updated at 8.19am GMT

7.41am GMT

Most of the bonuses being paid out by RBS will be in deferred shares and bonds -- cash payouts are restricted to £2,000 each.

At £576m, the total bonus pot (’total variable compensation’ in banker jargon) is 12% smaller than a year ago. But taxpayers may wonder why ‘their’ bank is handing over so much money in bonuses, after another sizeable loss.

Here’s the details (from this section of the financial results)

7.24am GMT

RBS posts another loss, and a £576m bonus pot

Good morning.

Royal Bank of Scotland has reported a pre-tax loss of £8.2bn for the last financial year, but will still pay bonuses of £576m, in a move that will inevitably fuel the debate over pay in the banking sector.

RBS announced to the City at 7am that it had made a loss for the sixth year in a row -- partly due to having to set aside more than £3.8bn to cover compensation payments and fines.

But despite another year in the red, RBS is planning to pay over half a billion pounds of bonuses. That’s down on the £679m paid in 2012, but unlikely to pacify critics who say City pay is out of hand.

RBS’s new CEO, Ross McEwan, is also announcing details of a new strategic review for RBS. It is based on refocusing the bank on its UK customers, and rebuilding trust in the company.

He’s speaking to journalists now, so we’ll have lots more detail and reaction through the next couple of hours.

A string of other companies are posting results this morning, including insurance group RSA (with delicious timing, it’s now being run by ex-RBS boss Stephen Hester). It has announced a £775m rights issue.

Standard Life, advertising giant WPP, housebuilder Redrow, theme park group Merlin, and Lego are also reporting -- but RBS could easily dominate the day.

I’ll round up all the key points -- along with our usual rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy and the eurozone.

Updated at 7.31am GMT
